title: CTRL0000087481 - Transcribed Interview of Jason Van Tatenhove, (July 7, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
INTERVIEW OF:
JASON VAN TATENHOVE
Thursday, July 7, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 12:05 p.m.
Present:
Representatives Lofgren and Murphy.
Appearances:
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
STAFF ASSOCIATE
CHIEF CLERK
INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
For JASON VAN TATENHOVE:
RAPHAEL A. PROBER
MIRANDA DORE
Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld LLP
Robert S. Strauss Tower
2001 K Street NW
Washington, D.C. 20006-1037
Good afternoon, everyone.
This is a transcribed interview of Jason Van Tatenhove by the U.S. House Select
Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol.
Mr. Van Tatenhove, can you please state your name and spell your last name?
Mr. Van Tatenhove.
Thank you, Mr. Van Tatenhove.
Last name is
As you know, I'm -
and I'm an investigative counsel with the select committee.
I have a couple of colleagues on the line.
It's Jason Russell Van Tatenhove.
spelled Vas in Victor, -a-n, separate word, T as in Thomas, -a-t-e-n-h-o-v- as in Victor, -e.
Sure.
and
are the line.
And, also, we have two members in attendance right now, Representative
Stephanie Murphy and Representative Zoe Lofgren.
If any additional members or additional staff join, I'll announce them at that point.
Mr. Van Tatenhove, I'll just note for the record that you're here voluntarily.
I just want to express my appreciation and the appreciation of our colleagues and team
for all of the help that you've provided us.
you've spoken with us, and we appreciate all of the help that you've provided all on a
voluntary basis.
I know this is the third or fourth time that
I'll also note for the record that you're represented by counsel today.
Can counsel for Mr. Van Tatenhove please state their names?
Mr. Prober.
Yes.
And
It's Raphael Prober and Miranda Dore from Akin Gump.
Great.
Thank you both.
Because this interview is being conducted on a voluntary basis, this proceeding
will not be under oath, but I'll just remind you, as we do with all of our witnesses, that it is
unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
Mr. Van Tatenhove, we're happy to take a break if you need one at any point.
And if you'd like to talk to your attorneys, we're happy to go off the record and give you
an opportunity to do so.
requests.
Mr. Van Tatenhove.
Mr. Van Tatenhove.
No, I don't think so.
Great.
Okay.
Do you have any questions before we get started?
Just let me know, and we're happy to accommodate your
All right.
Well, let's just dive in.
EXAMINATION
BY
Q
Mr. Van Tatenhove, in your own words, who are the Oath Keepers?
A
The Oath Keepers are a -- what I would term these days as a paramilitary
militia organization that started off more as an educational outreach group but, over
time, radicalized and became more and more of what we know of them today as the Oath
Keepers or a militia/paramilitary group.
Great.
Thank you.
Q
Why do you think someone would be drawn to joining the Oath Keepers?
A
Well, I can only speak from my own experience, but I know that membership
oftentimes came from people that, in my view, were somewhat disenfranchised with life;
they didn't have much going on.
feeling of being plugged in and connected, a chance to feel like they were doing
something important, so important that it could, you know, save the direction that the
And the Oath Keepers really kind of offered them a
country was going in, you know.
And, really, my opinion on this is, these notions that they were using to kind of
recruit from really were more of playing to the audience.
Stewart Rhodes espoused publicly didn't hold up in private conversation.
lot of things that it seemed that he didn't truly believe in but kind of catered his message
to to kind of maximize membership dues and donations.
Q
Got it.
That's really helpful.
A lot of the things that
There were a
And I'm going to return to some of those
themes later on, but just want to ask about your involvement specifically.
So when and how were you involved with the Oath Keepers?
A
So my involvement started back during Bundy Ranch.
And that's when I
was an independent journalist.
I was working for a small, little internet radio operation.
And I actually was able to become embedded with Stewart Rhodes in his vehicle as he
headed down for the second trip he made to Bundy Ranch.
in the mix with things with Stewart throughout Bundy Ranch.
And I was there and kind of
And then I was invited to go cover the Sugar Pine Mine standoff that happened in
the Pacific Northwest and then the White Hope Mine standoff that happened in
Montana.
During the White Hope Mine standoff, I had been helping their what they termed
as a public information officer with, you know, helping them just get a press release
ready, and they had included my name on that press release without my knowledge or
permission.
State of Montana.
And so that led to me having to resign from my day job working for the
However, I was offered a position -- Stewart Rhodes offered me a position as the
national media director -- this was in August of 2015 -- and associate editor for their web
page.
And that began a about-a-year-and-a-half journey where I was employed by the
Oath Keepers -- I was never a member of the Oath Keepers; I was an employee of the
Oath Keepers -- that culminated pretty much at the end of 2016 and ran into 2017 little
bit.
But, as things began to become ever-radicalizing, you know, with the courting of
people like Richard Spencer, you know, that really raised some red flags for me, and there
were some incidents that led me to move on from the Oath Keepers at that point.
Got it.
That's really helpful.
Q
And how would you describe your relationship with Stewart Rhodes during that
time?
A
I definitely had an insider's view.
We worked closely together, especially
once -- so, once I accepted the job in August of 2015, I was moved up to the Eureka,
Montana, area, where I lived on property that was owned by large financial supporters of
the Oath Keepers.
And we would have daily contact.
We would see each other most weeks.
We
oftentimes would travel together to different events happening throughout the country
during my tenure there with the Oath Keepers.
So, you know -- and it's a small mountain town, so there's not a lot of social
outlets in a place like that.
as friends, really.
leadership of the Oath Keepers.
So we actually became close on an interpersonal level, just
And so I feel that kind of gave me a unique inside view to the
And, you know, Stewart Rhodes really is the Oath Keepers.
He is the president
and founder and really is the person who had the vision and made all the decisions.
That's really helpful.
Q
I think in one or two of our prior conversations you mentioned that Mr. Rhodes
actually lived with you for a period of time.
Can you describe that?
A
Yeah.
So, in early to mid 2018, Stewart Rhodes was asked to leave his
house by his wife and children.
and he literally had no place else to go.
There was divorce proceedings beginning to happen,
And, at that point in time, I had pretty much washed my hands of everything.
had very much tried to just have a clean break.
property that was owned by the supporters to a separate property in the area and had
begun to move on with my life.
You know, I moved my family from the
Stewart showed up on my front door, knocking, asking if he could stay there for a
little while because he had nowhere else to go, so he wound up couch-surfing in my
basement.
close to 8 months.
Q
Got it.
A
Not -- not at all.
Q
Great.
I will just note for the record that my colleague
And that wound up being much longer than anticipated.
It wound up being
And have you had contact with Mr. Rhodes since then?
also joined the
meeting.
So I'm going to go into some specific questions about the Oath Keepers and about
Mr. Rhodes, but, before I do that, do any of my colleagues or any of the members have
questions about the, kind of, scene-setting background questions that we just covered?
Ms. Lofgren.
I don't.
Okay.
Thank you, Ms. Lofgren.
BY
I did want to follow up on one background question just before we move on.
Q
So you mentioned that there were some mounting concerns that you had about
the organization.
Is there anything else that you'd like to add about why you left the
Oath Keepers and why you broke ties with Stewart Rhodes?
A
Well, I can trace it to, kind of, this -- as I mentioned before, there was this
radicalization that I witnessed happening from Bundy Ranch on.
And, each time, it
seemed to get -- each increment seemed to go further to what I would call the alt-right,
which was kind of a rising force in national politics and in the media cycle.
It came to a culmination with -- the straw that broke the camel's back, really, was
during a -- it was actually just a social setting, in a grocery store up in Eureka, Montana,
where some close associates and some longtime members of, kind of, the core group of
Oath Keepers were having an open discussion, and that discussion revolved around the
subject matter of whether or not the Holocaust was a real, legitimate piece of history.
And that, for me, was -- I just couldn't abide by it.
And so I left that conversation,
went home, and told my wife I didn't care how we were going to break away but that we
were going to find some way to do it, that I just could no longer be involved in any way in
a group that was heading this direction.
So we, you know, within a month, found a new place to live -- and at great
financial hardship, I might add.
wife's
know, at that point it didn't matter whether or not we were going to survive financially.
It really was just, we'll find a way.
You know, we were living below the poverty line.
I have two daughters who were still in the house.
So, you
So that was kind of the culmination, the point where I said, I just can't have
anything more to do with this.
Got it.
That's really helpful.
Q
And that flows well into my next question about the kind of ideology, political
My
philosophy of the Oath Keepers.
You know, Stewart Rhodes and a lot of Oath Keeper leaders publicly deny that
they're White supremacists, that they're racist.
race or on any sorts of social issues in the country?
A
How would you describe their views on
I think you need to break this into two different segments.
I think the first
one needs to be what is publicly messaged out to the world and his followers, and then
what is discussed kind of behind closed doors.
Do I believe that Stewart Rhodes himself is a racist?
I do not, just based on
personal conversations.
conspiracy theories like the "They will not replace us" thing that we're seeing rise in
prominence these days.
However, I think that he is fine with selling the notion of
You know, a lot of the lifeblood of these communities is what the hot conspiracy
theories are of the day.
out and find hot-button news items every morning and figure out a way that we could
kind of cater that messaging to potential donors and potential membership -- so, you
know, the immigration issues down on the southern border and whatnot.
Part of my job as associate editor for the web page was to go
You know, it's a well-known -- it's been well-known through different media
interviews and such with Stewart Rhodes that his mother actually came from the
immigrant community that worked down in the Southwest.
me of moving around a lot because his mother was working in the agricultural industry
kind of on a seasonal basis and that that was -- you know, that was where his true beliefs
came from.
He had related stories to
But, you know, in the end, the messaging that he put out into the public sphere
was very much a radicalized message that seemed to always be increasing.
And we saw
that when, you know, he started courting people like Richard Spencer and providing
security for these individuals that were obviously White nationalists and racist and, I
would even say, straight-out Nazis at times.
Q
I understand that a core element of the Oath Keepers philosophy is that they're
Got it.
skeptical of government leaders.
Why do you think Donald Trump was different?
what about President Trump was appealing to the Oath Keepers?
A
When President Trump originally was -- during his first election day, Stewart
And
Well, again, this is an evolving story.
wasn't even going to go vote.
I know this because I was in communication with him and
saying, "Look, you gotta go down and vote."
Clinton, who Stewart had a very large disdain for.
You know, it's just, Trump wasn't Hillary
But I think he saw opportunity -- and this is a theme that we'll see echoed
throughout the story as we move on -- he saw opportunity with the Trump
administration.
He saw an opportunity for legitimacy in the public eye.
You know, I think there are a couple different factors that motivated Stewart
Rhodes, one of which being kind of an ego-driven fantasy of becoming a paramilitary
leader; the other being, obviously, money through donations and whatnot.
But I think that it was a relationship of convenience, and that became more and
more entrenched as things moved forward from the election on, that there were
opportunities presented for being seen as a legitimate force, for Stewart Rhodes, with
aligning with Trump, and that it would open doors that had been closed up until this
point.
Q
Were there particular things that President Trump did or said that you saw
as appealing to the Oath Keepers or to Stewart Rhodes?
A
Now, again, I need to preface that, you know, by the time Trump was
elected and in office, I had broken ties, so this is just my opinion.
But, yes, I think there was a lot that resounded with the Oath Keepers -- you
know, specifically the mention to the Proud Boys of "stand back and stand by."
know, I think that was seen by a lot of the communities, these paramilitary/militia
communities, as a direct message to them that there were plans afoot and they were a
part of those plans.
You
I think that, you know -- I think the administration, in my opinion, tried to reach
out and open lines of communication with these militia groups.
Q
Can you expand on that?
A
I can.
And, again, this happened after I had broken ties, but I was still kind
of in the loop as far as information-sharing with different people within that community.
I had received a call after I had left the Oath Keepers talking about a specific
meeting outside of Pahrump, Nevada, I believe it was, where Roger Stone was going to
be -- had asked to have an impromptu meeting with some militia leaders, including the
Bundys.
And, you know, they had actually invited -- wanted to see if I wanted to go out
there as a representative of the Oath Keepers.
It was fairly -- you know, I explained that
I had nothing to do with them now and was not interested whatsoever.
But I thought it was telling that -- and certainly concerning -- that someone so
close to the campaign at that point would be reaching out to, you know, known militia
members that had taken stands previously, with, you know, firearms involved, both on
private property and on Federal property.
and something that stuck with me.
So it certainly was a concerning thing to me
I don't really have much information beyond that.
I know it's all hearsay, but,
you know, I do think there is truth to it.
Q
Do you recall what the purpose of that meeting was, or the stated purpose?
A
From my understanding, my recollection, it was just to open lines of
communication, kind of almost like a meet-and-greet.
don't know.
Q
Got it.
And, other than that, I really
And were you told anything about whether it was on behalf of the
campaign?
A
I did not.
Q
Okay.
So I want to ask specifically about a theme that emerged in 2020 in Stewart
No.
Got it.
Rhodes' rhetoric.
So, as I'm sure you've seen, leading up to January 6th, Stewart Rhodes described
repeatedly in public that he wanted President Trump to invoke the Insurrection Act and
call up an unorganized militia that would've included the Oath Keepers.
Did Mr. Rhodes ever discuss the Insurrection Act with you at the time that you
were in touch?
A
He mentioned it briefly and in passing.
I didn't know too much about what
the Insurrection Act was at the time.
always kind of heading towards becoming a paramilitary figure, kind of almost like a folk
hero figure.
anyway.
Q
And so it certainly falls in line with his character and what I saw of it,
So, you know, I'll preface this question by acknowledging that I know you can
only offer your thoughts in the context of your prior conversations with Mr. Rhodes.
But, you know, if step number one is President Trump invoking the Insurrection
But he was -- it seemed like his end game was
Act, what is step number two as it relates to Stewart Rhodes and the Oath Keepers?
A
Well, again, this would just be my opinion and thinking out loud really.
But,
really, we've seen Stewart talk about and, you know, put into place quick reaction forces
before.
And, you know, heading to the U.S. Capitol with a military force, in military
formations, dressed as a military does, with military-grade firearms and weapons,
obviously I think that means that he was willing to move forward with trying some sort of
violent takeover of the U.S. Government.
Q
Uh-huh.
A
And, again, that's just me theorizing.
Q
Sure.
You know, you talked earlier about how, you know, President Trump presented an
opportunity to Mr. Rhodes.
seen reported publicly about January 6th and about the actions of the Oath Keepers?
A
Can you expand on that in the context of what you have
I think that -- again, just theorizing -- I think that lines of communication
probably were successfully opened at some point in time after my tenure.
I think there
probably was communication in some aspect, whether it was directly with Trump or just
members of his circle.
Stone with security there at the Stop the Steal rally before the events at the Capitol
Building.
Obviously, we saw that certain Oath Keepers provided Roger
So, you know, I think that there definitely was communication happening.
as far as how much it was planned out, obviously we saw the footage with Oath Keepers
leadership, Stewart Rhodes himself, and Enrique Tarrio down in the basement.
that was just a platitude, I don't know.
acknowledging that both groups were there or if it was more in-depth planning, that's
something I don't really know much about.
And,
Whether
You know, whether it was just kind of
But, obviously, there were different groups there and involved, and they were
there for a reason.
And I think the speeches that Trump put forward and the messaging
that had been happening on Twitter and in social media really paints a stark picture as to
what their intentions were.
Great.
That's very helpful.
Q
So what I'd like to do is -- so the select committee has obtained several encrypted
chats from Stewart Rhodes in the weeks leading up to January 6th.
I'd like to just read
out loud a couple of them and kind of get your reaction to them in the context of what
you know about Stewart Rhodes' messaging in the past and the conversations you've had
with him, kind of have you interpret or translate based off the fact that you were the
former spokesman of the Oath Keepers.
Does that sound okay?
A
Yes.
Q
So, in one message from December 2020, Stewart Rhodes wrote to the
Florida Oath Keepers, quote, "We need to push Trump to do his duty.
will do ours.
to be our attitude," end quote.
If he doesn't, we
Declare independence, defy, resist, defend, conquer, or die.
This needs
So, Mr. Van Tatenhove, how do you interpret that quoted message in the context
of what you've heard Mr. Rhodes say in the past?
A
It falls right in line with his messaging, though more extreme.
Usually
Stewart's very measured in his public responses.
response, but, you know, Stewart, being a Vale-educated lawyer, is very good at toeing
the line between what will get him in trouble and what won't, which is why we haven't
seen any repercussions for the actions previously.
And, obviously, this wasn't a public
But, really, that -- you know, he seems more emboldened and felt that he could
push the line, obviously, to something that seems more of an insurrection in and of itself.
You know, the words speak for themselves, in that it seems that he's calling for a
revolution, and if the President's not gonna do it, that doesn't matter; we're gonna go
forward and do it anyway, do it on our own.
Great.
Thank you.
Q
In another message -- and this was from December 29, 2020, so just a couple of
days before January 6th -- Stewart Rhodes sent a private message to another individual
saying the following:
Quote, "This will be D.C. rally number three.
give a shit how many show up and wave a sign, pray, or yell.
come with rifles in hand.
our gloves off and kicking ass.
Congress.
Getting kind of old.
They don't
They won't fear us till we
Only reason to go is so Trump knows we support him in taking
That's why I'm going.
It's to send him a message, not
I'm done talking to them."
Mr. Van Tatenhove, how do you interpret those messages in the context of what
you've heard Mr. Rhodes say in the past?
A
I think it's him using pressure through membership ranks to try to put a
message out to the Trump administration saying, "Look, we want you to do this, and if
you're not gonna do it, we're gonna do it anyway."
You know, again, he -- I think it was a relationship of convenience.
And he may
have been worried about Trump wavering in the moment, and trying to shore up his own
troops, so to say, and kind of get them ready for what he had envisioned happening on
January 6th.
Q
Did you ever hear the Oath Keepers discussing violence against politicians?
A
I certainly heard Stewart brainstorming about violent acts, specifically
intimidation, not necessarily -- you know, he never spoke about outright, you
know -- other than in the public papers he did, where he would talk about hanging Hillary
Clinton by the neck for treason.
But there were projects he would bring to me that certainly intimated violent
actions.
One of the first projects he wanted me to do on a graphics level was create a card
deck, much like we saw in the Gulf War where we had different generals and people that
were wanted by the U.S. military, Armed Forces, where they would create a playing card
deck with, kind of, the who's who of who they wanted to bring in and get rid of.
wanted to do that with people such as Hillary Clinton.
And that's a project I just outright refused to do.
And he
But it does show that he
certainly was thinking in military terms and using similar propaganda techniques to kind
of instill a sense of, "Violent actions need to be taken."
Q
Got it.
Do you remember any of the other politicians who would've been
featured on those cards?
A
I don't, not off the top of my head.
Q
No worries.
Did the Oath Keepers ever provide weapons to members?
A
weapons.
They certainly provided ammunition.
I don't know if they provided actual
But I can tell you that, when I first went down to Bundy Ranch, one of the pit stops
we made along the way was to -- it was in the middle of the night, so I really had no idea
where we were.
where -- a horse trailer had been following us, with a large pickup truck, and we had
stopped in the middle of the night to load up on storable food and such, but there was a
large amount of ammunition that was also put into the vehicle.
I think it was in Clinton, believe it or not, Montana, somewhere,
I know that there was also a storefront in Kalispell, Montana, where ammunition
was available for those who may have needed it and were given out freely at the time.
So, yeah, ammunition was certainly given.
As far as weapons themselves, no.
do know there were a couple of FLIR units -- forward-looking infrared -- scopes that were
donated that Stewart had talked about and showed me in the car ride down to Bundy
Ranch.
But, other than -- there were raffles and fundraising events where AR-15s and
assault rifles were offered up as the prizes for these membership drives.
Got it.
That's really helpful.
Q
So we've heard testimony from some rioters from January 6th that President
Trump's focus on January 6th really deeply influenced their decision to come to D.C., that
they thought the date was important but the events were important because of President
Trump, that his messages on social media had a powerful impact on them, and that
people felt disillusioned and unheard and that President Trump took advantage of those
feelings.
You know, based on your experience with Stewart Rhodes, in your view, how did
far-right leaders like Stewart Rhodes take advantage of that kind of disillusionment that
the rioters have described?
Absolutely.
And that's something that goes back to my first days with the
A
Oath Keepers.
membership, you know, they're going after disenfranchised people.
You know, much like we see with actual Nazi groups that are recruiting
Now, the Oath Keepers certainly talks a lot about having a large military base, as
far as retired military, you know, veterans and such.
Most of those members, in my
experience, have been non-combat veterans, that they fulfilled more administrative jobs.
And a lot of them didn't have -- again, as I said earlier, didn't have much going on in their
lives.
They felt unheard.
He really played along the vibes of rural and urban communities and the feeling
that rural communities just are not being heard by their State and national lawmakers.
And that was part of the initiative, really, to gain membership, was to play on those
feelings of isolation and not being heard and really, you know, trying to find people that
needed something to live for, and present them with, "Hey, well, we're doing this.
can come plug in with us and, you know, be a part of something historic, be a part of
something important that's going to help save this country."
Q
You
So, in the weeks leading up to January 6th, just based off of what you saw
and your familiarity with this community, were you concerned that President Trump was
tapping into those same feelings that people like Stewart Rhodes had exploited?
A
Absolutely.
I see a lot of similarities with the tactics that President Trump
used and Stewart Rhodes and other leadership figures amongst these different
communities.
lot -- they all, you know, tie in with the same type of propaganda and social media usage
that we see coming out of lnfoWars and Alex Jones's outlet, and a lot of the talking points
are very, very similar.
They seem to all be reading from the same playback.
You know, a
So, yes, I see this as, kind of, you know, a group of people that saw places where
they could take advantage of people's feelings.
true technique within the media, to, you know, touch upon these emotional hothouses
and use that to try to further their own agendas.
Q
And, you know, that's an old tried and
Were you concerned about the temperature of things or the way that things
were headed leading up to January 6th?
A
I was, but I will say that I underestimated things.
You know, having an
inside view for so long, I felt there was -- there was a certain amount of incompetence,
and, you know, it just seemed like there wasn't much that could happen there.
there they were, you know, in some of the most iconic, historic moments of our country
thus far, you know, running up the stairs of the U.S. Capitol in a stacked, military wedge
And yet
formation.
So I underestimated them, and I was wrong in doing so, I think, in that, you know,
they were able to garner enough support and people to literally head up to the Capitol in
a stacked formation.
So, you know, I think -- I feared for what may have been -- what may have
happened if there was someone a bit more competent at the helm.
got lucky.
country may be going in the future.
But lucky is not a good survival tactic.
You know, I fear for where the
So what was different about January 6th and the lead-up to January 6th?
Q
And, thankfully, we
You know, you described how there was this strain of incompetence among the Oath
Keepers.
outside observer?
A
What was different this time, based off of your, you know, perspective as an
The rhetoric had certainly become much more extreme -- the rhetoric, the
messaging.
You know, it just seemed like the whole world was becoming more extreme,
and Stewart in his messaging was keeping pace with that, if not trying to lead the pack.
And, you know, I think it's just, again, tying into what the hot-button issues of the
day are.
You know, those were the hot-button issues of the day, and Stewart was using
them to great effect, to motivate people to go to the Capitol and to attempt an assault on
it.
So, you know, it was a continuation of this, you know, ever-growing extremism
that was just -- you know, it seemed to be in this echo chamber and just growing and
growing.
Q
So, when you say the rhetoric was heating up and that, you know, Stewart
and others were taking advantage of it, are you talking about President Trump's rhetoric?
A
President Trump's, Stewart's rhetoric, everybody's.
It seemed like all of it
was rising in temperature.
Got it.
That's really helpful.
Q
Let me pause here and see if any of my colleagues or any of the members have
questions.
Okay.
We actually, you know, speeded through the main questions that I wanted to
cover.
return to a couple of points today.
We had a multi-hour conversation the last time around, and I just wanted to
Are there things that you observed about January 6th or President Trump's
influence on the Oath Keepers that we haven't covered today?
A
You know, I think the main takeaway I took from it was, especially with the
information that's come out afterwards with the encrypted messaging and such, that, you
know, it seemed that President Trump had influenced and kind of given the green light
for these people, but, really, the fact that they were willing to move forward even after
President Trump seemed to pause and even step back and not go to the Capitol himself,
and, you know, with Stewart's messaging saying, you know, "We're gonna do this

What would you say to them?
I would say, as someone who has been in the mix, got swept up a bit, but
then walked away, that there are exit ramps, that you don't have to continue to
participate in these echo chambers where -- you know, you need to look at the end
games of things and what country we wind up living in and what country our children and
our grandchildren wind up living in, and is this really going the direction you want it to
go?
you feel valued and plugged in and doing important things, without, you know, falling for,

work towards a better future that's better for everybody all around.
